items.message:
This flood alert has been issued due to high spring tides. The forecast high water is 06:30 on 29/09/23 with a level of 6.26 mAOD and a Force 5 north-westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high-water time at Hinkley. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail please refer to local tide tables. 

Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at this time and conditions may apply either side of the high tide. Flooding is possible for the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this time.

Flood Alert conditions are expected to continue throughout this sequence of high spring tides which peak on Saturday evening 30/09/2023 and continue into next week. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads, and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.

We are monitoring the situation closely and this message will be updated by midday on Friday 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels continue to remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. Further rain is expected throughout the night, which will keep the levels high, but we are not expecting to see any significant changes.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00am on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Warning has been issued because flooding is expected today and through the night on Thursday 28/09/2023 into Friday 29/09/2023.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Greta, River Derwent, Derwent Water lake level, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.
River levels remain high at the Lodore gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

Thursday evening's tide at 23:45 on 28/09/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Southerly Force 6 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.17 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane.  The tide levels are a little elevated and will be broadly similar over the next 4 days. This may cause some impacts at each high water until Monday 02/10/2023‚ but where impacts do occur‚ they will be very minor. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping.  Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 10:00 on 29/09/2023.

As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest this evening at 09:00PM on 28/09/2023.
Flooding is possible at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon from 08:00 PM until 10:00 PM on 28/09/2023. with the local tide level forecast to reach 1.28m.
The high tides on Friday and Saturday evening are expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
We are closely monitoring the situation remotely. We are not expecting to shut pedestrian tide gates this evening but will monitor closely.
Consider activating any property flood protection products.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest this evening at 08:00PM on 28/09/2023.
Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle between 07:00 PM until 9:30 PM on 28/09/2023. with the local tide level forecast to reach 1.28m.
The high tides on Friday and Saturday evening are expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We are closely monitoring the situation remotely. We are not expecting to shut any pedestrian tide gates this evening but will monitor closely.
Consider activating any property flood protection products.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from The Rumps to Hartland Point excluding Bude
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced.  However, as we move towards the highest tides of the year this weekend, further flooding is possible with flood alerts expected to be reissued on Friday.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from Chapel Porth to The Rumps excluding the tidal River Camel
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced.  However, as we move towards the highest tides of the year this weekend, further flooding is possible with flood alerts expected to be reissued on Friday.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High spring tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow (29/09/2023). Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point. Flooding is possible between 03:30am to 06:00am on Friday morning and between 4:30pm to 6:30pm on Friday afternoon. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: High spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning (29/09/2023). Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, including Hornsea between 03:15am to 05:00am on 29/09/2023. High astronomical tides will continue over the next few days peaking on Saturday. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: High spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning (29/09/2023). Areas most at risk are Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck between 03:15am to 05:00am on 29/09/2023. High astronomical tides will continue over the next few days peaking on Saturday 30/09/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous.  This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: High spring tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow (29/09/2023). Areas most at risk include Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall. Flooding is possible between 03:15am to 06:30am on Friday morning and 4pm to 7pm on Friday afternoon. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

As a result of high spring tides, flooding of roads and farmland is possible on the high tides at 19:30 today, 28/09/23 and 07:45 tomorrow, 29/09/23. A series of high tides is due over the next 5 days. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.1m to 7.4m at 19:30 on 28/09/23 and 7.2m to 7.5m at 08:00 on 29/09/23. Newport 6.9m to 7.2m at 19:30 on 28/09/23 and 6.9m to 7.2m at 07:45 on 29/09/23.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 14:00 on 29/09/23, or as the situation changes.

As a result of strong winds and spring tides, tides will be high and may cause flooding until Monday 2nd October.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads at Fiddler’s Ferry, Eastford Road and Arpley Bridge peaking tonight between at 00:00 and 01:00 at between 6.4m to 6.7m. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. This situation is likely to repeated for every high tide from now until Monday 2nd October, with high tides coinciding with spring tides. There are two high tides a day, with the night tides being higher than the day time high tides.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides, tides will be at their highest overnight on 28/09/2023 at 11:30PM.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
With high spring tides, this situation is likely to be repeated for every high tide from now until Monday 2nd October.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 08:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

items.description: Coast from Silloth to St Bees
items.message:
We do not expect the morning high tide to reach flood alert level.

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the weekend as a result of the high spring tides. It is expected that we will issue further alerts or warnings as these tides approach.

As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest overnight at 11:30 PM on Thursday 28/09/2023.
Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.
No property flooding is expected.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 5 days and as a result we will issue further alerts or warnings.
Our incident response staff have closed flood gates and we will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on Friday 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tides forecast from early Friday morning on 29/09/2023.

Flooding to low lying land, roads and footpaths is possible between 02:30 AM and 04:30 AM. Areas most at risk include from Wylam to the North Sea coast, including Watergate Car Park at Newcastle Quayside. 

Tide levels are expected to be higher than usual due to the high spring tides. The early morning tides for Saturday and Monday are also forecast to be higher than usual, and therefore we expect this alert to remain in force over the weekend. We will continue to monitor levels closely. 

Please stay away from riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 17:00PM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes

We do not expect the morning high tide to reach flood alert level.

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the weekend as a result of the high spring tides. It is expected that we will issue further alerts or warnings as these tides approach.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Haverigg
items.message:
We do not expect the morning high tide to reach flood alert level.

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the weekend as a result of the high spring tides. It is expected that we will issue further alerts or warnings as these tides approach.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Little Alne river gauge as a result of expected heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 29/09/23. Flooding may affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Arrow between Studley and Salford Priors and the River Alne between Bird in Hand and Alcester on the River Alne including farmland and caravan parks.
Rainfall is forecast overnight. We expect river levels to rise overnight until tomorrow morning, 29/09/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 29/09/23, or as the situation changes.
